div.p: In a letter of 3 March 1823 to John James Ruskin, Margaret Ruskin mentions receiving this publication (Ruskin Family Letters, ed. Burd, 121). Her remark does not make clear when she began her subscription; notably, however, with the 1823 issues, the magazine initiated volume 1 of a new series, having begun publication in 1793.

Regular reading of the Evangelical Magazine necessarily entailed an interest in missionary work, since a significant portion of each issue was devoted to reporting missionary news and especially to promoting the efforts of the London Missionary Society (LMS). The magazine supported other interests, as well, which would have engaged the Ruskin family, including poetry; articles primarily on religious topics but encompassing other areas of knowledge, such as natural history; reviews and notices of religious publications; obituaries and biographies of celebrated clergy, embellished by an engraved portrait of a clergyman in each issue; and as an effect of missionary news, exposure to peoples, landscapes, and customs of cultures around the world--an exposure that was of course filtered through the perception of the missionaries reporting on their experiences.

Doctrinally, the magazine claimed a pan-evangelical catholicity of non-affiliation. This position became difficult to maintain: a "Retrospect" published at the start of the new series admitted to the emergence of rival publications specific to denominations; and like the LMS it represented, the magazine became increasingly centered in Congregationalism ("Retrospect of the Former Series of the Evangelical Magazine", 1; Altholz, ???). Nonetheless, as Sujit Sivasundaram argues, the magazine offered readers a collective experience of evangelical zeal and meditation; and by reporting on charitable contributions to the LMS, from small donations such as used copies of the magazine to be sent to missionaries abroad, to more substantial cash donations, readers felt they participated in a worldwide evangelistic effort ("The Periodical as Barometer", 43-48). In the outreach for charitable support, the magazine formed but one part of what Anna Johnston describes as the LMS's construction of "a reading audience through its canny manipulation of textual and media technologies, a readership that would unite religious Britons in a common cause despite differences of class, region, gender, and age" ("British Missionary Publishing", 30).
